Joel Turner suffered a badly broken jaw after being struck while trying to break up a fight at a party in Brisbane. He was admitted to hospital where doctors operated on and wired his jaw back together.

Between 1957 and 1962, Tonga Fou witnessed the British military detonate thermonuclear weapons on Christmas Island (Kiritimati), where he recalled the terrifying experience of seeing a mushroom cloud with "bright colors, like breaking waves of fire" rising into the sky after one explosion that shook the boat where he and his family had huddled.

In Zihuatanejo, a rare phenomenon of shark attacks that had created a "Jaws-like mania" eventually subsided after the sharks dispersed from the area, which had previously led to the construction of lifeguard towers and establishment of a shark patrol for local beaches.

Eric Hoffer spent many years "wandering up and down the land, dodging hunger and grieving over the world" after being orphaned at eighteen, during which time he worked various jobs including as a field hand, dishwasher, and longshoreman while developing his philosophical ideas that would later be published in his acclaimed book "The True Believer."

West Virginia dominated East Carolina in the first half of their football game, holding the Pirates to just 2 yards rushing while gaining 221 yards to East Carolina's 87, though they only led 14-7 at halftime due to two interceptions thrown by White in the end zone.

For this achievement, Rockwell was awarded the Medaille Militaire and the Croix de Guirre, gaining international recognition before his eventual death in combat just four months later.

1. Earner: the Financial Transaction Reports and Analysis Center (PPATK)
Summary: The Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) in Indonesia investigated irregularities in the e-KTP project, finding that Rp 2.3 trillion (US $172 million) had been stolen from the electronic identity card procurement project, causing significant state losses. The KPK received details from the Financial Transaction Reports and Analysis Center (PPATK) regarding the flow of these funds through four firms that were part of the State Printing Company (PNRI) Consortium.

Topic: artists that don't write their own songs
Summary: The Experiencer expresses being thankful for artists like Britney while simultaneously not understanding how artists can't write their own music, as they view songwriting as a personal form of expression.

On July 4th, over 3,000 fans who couldn't get tickets to the sold-out baseball game at Nettleton Stadium gathered in neighboring fields and parking lots to cheer for the team and enjoy the post-game fireworks show, contributing to a record attendance for the Golden Baseball League event.

Summary: Everton's unwarranted approach to hire Marco Silva jeopardized the long-term future of Watford FC, leading to a significant deterioration in both focus and results. As a resolution, Everton agreed to pay £4 million in compensation to Watford to end the dispute over Silva's appointment.

In December 2004, SEPA (State Environmental Protection Administration) enforced environmental laws and regulations in China through what was hailed as "an environmental storm," suspending the construction of about 30 big projects that failed to have proper environmental impact assessments. Despite this action, Professor Wang Canfa observed that SEPA alone cannot guarantee the full enforcement of environmental laws and regulations.

The event commemorated the 50th anniversary of mass conversions to Buddhism initiated by Dr. Ambedkar, bringing together over 60 representatives from various Buddhist organizations to discuss issues facing the Dalit communities in India.

In 1097, Kim Pusik qualified in the government entrance examination on the Book of Documents, which was an important step in his career as a Korean statesman, historian, and general who later became a minister in the Koryó dynasty government.

The Fremantle Dockers traded defender Chris Tarrant to Collingwood in exchange for draft picks 43 and 55 during the AFL's trade period. Fremantle also gave up pick 44 to the Magpies as part of the deal, with Tarrant returning to his former club where he had previously played nine seasons before joining the Dockers in 2007.

Plan: a new feature called virtual machine control structure (VMCS) shadowing

Summary: Processor developers like Intel have implemented VMCS shadowing, a new feature that extends the capabilities of Intel-VT and provides additional flexibility in resource virtualization and sharing. This feature is implemented on the processor as part of the CPU's virtualization capabilities to address performance issues in systems hosting multiple VMMs.

James Hanratty was hanged at Bedford Prison on Wednesday, April 4, 1962, for the murder of Michael Gregsten during the notorious A6 Murder case. Despite years of campaigning by his family claiming his innocence, DNA evidence later confirmed his guilt in the crime.

In the 2nd Century BC, the famous Greek physician Galen developed a variety of exercises that required the use of halteres, which were weights with handles commonly used in Ancient Greek training regimes since the 5th Century BC. Galen's compilation of halteres exercises for the whole body contributed significantly to the growth of their popularity globally.

In 1998, a Spanish court requested the extradition of former Chilean president Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, who was arrested in England while on a medical visit. Pinochet, accused of murder, torture and conspiracy to murder, applied to have the arrest warrant quashed on grounds of immunity as a former Head of State, but the House of Lords ruled in a 3:2 majority that he was not entitled to immunity from criminal proceedings and could therefore be extradited.

Summary: Fish farmers in some regions of Asia inject glassfish with fluorescent dyes to create distinctive color patterns, a practice that has been criticized by Practical Fishkeeping magazine for its cruelty and health risks to the fish. The magazine has campaigned to educate retailers and aquarists about these issues in an effort to remove these artificially colored fish from the market.

Summary: Major League Baseball fined David Ortiz an undisclosed amount on Tuesday for making contact with home plate umpire John Tumpane during Sunday's game against the Baltimore Orioles at Fenway Park. In addition to the fine, Ortiz received a one-game suspension which he has elected to appeal.

Ravens head coach John Harbaugh fired Cam Cameron from his position as offensive coordinator in December, but stated that Cameron deserved and would receive a Super Bowl ring for helping the team reach the playoffs, despite not being with them during their Super Bowl XLVII victory against the San Francisco 49ers.

Adrastus fled from Thebes to Athens, where he sought help at the altar of Mercy. This led to Theseus marching on Thebes, capturing the city and recovering the dead, following which Evadne jumped on her husband's burning pyre.

Iran-backed parties with links to militia groups performed poorly in the election compared to their previous showing in 2018.

In the 2020 Netflix Original movie "The Half of It," a shy, introverted student named Ellie Chu helps the school jock attempt to woo a girl, though secretly both Ellie and the jock are interested in the same girl.

In 2007, the Sunrise camp on Brownsea Island brought together 310 young people from 155 countries to celebrate the centenary of Scouting, marking 100 years since Robert Baden-Powell established the first scout camp on the same island.

In 2001, Clifford Peeples was jailed for ten years after being caught with hand grenades and a pipe bomb in his car, shocking many members of the Bethel Pentecostal Church where he was the assistant pastor. This behavior allows the falcons to have fresh food available when needed, as they pluck the flight feathers of their prey or trap them in tight holes to prevent escape.

The BBC moved Steven Spielberg's World War II epic "Band of Brothers" from BBC One to BBC Two to allow for an "uninterrupted ten-week run" of the series, denying claims that the move was due to the show not being mainstream enough.

Cheung Tze-keung, also known as "Big Spender," kidnapped two SAR tycoons in 1996 and 1997, collecting over $1.6 billion in ransom money. He allegedly pocketed $738 million from these kidnappings, though he later lost $300 million gambling in the United States and Macau.

First Lieutenant Fridrichs Feldmanis of the Latvian Army was shot dead by U.S.S.R. NKVD units at Litene, Latvia, between August 1 and 10, 1941. Summary: Former Homeland Security secretary Jeh Johnson led an independent commission that found both overt and institutional racism to be a pervasive problem in the New York State court system. Former Anglo Irish Bank chairman Sean Fitzpatrick was charged with 16 counts for permitting the bank to give unlawful financial assistance to 16 named individuals, including the "Maple Ten" group of Irish Investors and several members of Sean Quinn's family, between July 10 and July 17, 2008 for the purpose of purchasing shares in the bank.

Syedna went from Ahmedabad to Lahore where he was received by the emperor who was influenced by his spirituality. After his stay, Syedna returned to Ahmedabad under the emperor's protection with a Royal Farman that ordered officials to respect him for his learning, virtue, and piety.

At the Martian south pole, steep slopes known as 'scarps', composed almost entirely of water ice, fall away from the polar cap to the surrounding plains. These scarps are part of the transition area called the 'cryptic region' where clusters of geysers are located.

In 2015, Derek White drove the #40 Toyotas and Dodges at Bristol as part of MBM Motorsports, a team he formed with Carl Long in 2014. White secured the 40th starting position but pulled off the track after only 11 laps due to electrical issues, finishing last in the race.

In 2009, Aer Arann operated flights to Cork via Dublin, though they later reduced this service to six times per week. The airline established domestic service to Dublin and has since expanded to operate over 600 flights per week across 40 routes in Ireland, the UK, and Europe.

Entertainment Weekly's Owen Gleiberman noted that director Fred Durst attempted to have viewers sympathize with the rebel character Mick in "The Education of Charlie Banks," despite Mick's violent tendencies, though this sympathy "doesn't take" according to the review.

This global scheme has cost businesses more than $2 billion over approximately two years, affecting more than 12,000 victims worldwide.

The bath house at Ravenglass Roman Fort has been well-preserved due to its adaptation for domestic use in the medieval period. The remains, which stand almost 4 meters high, are among the tallest Roman structures surviving in northern Britain and are now in the care of English Heritage.

A large hippo was observed charging with an underwater attack on a speedboat in waterways in Malawi, Africa, creating its own wake before breaking the surface. The incident occurred near Dsoka, Malawi, forcing the boat's pilot to power forward and veer to avoid the charging animal.

In 2003, the Herzog Commission, led by former German President Roman Herzog, recommended decoupling health and nursing care premiums from people's earnings and instead implementing a monthly lump sum across the board as part of reform proposals drafted in response to Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's "Agenda 2010."

Flammables: the main stand of the club 's home ground
Cause: Ken Richardson who offered pounds 10,000 to a former SAS soldier to start the fire
Summary: In 1995, Ken Richardson orchestrated an arson plot by paying Alan Kristiansen, a former SAS soldier, £10,000 to start a fire at Doncaster Rovers' Belle Vue ground, targeting the main stand and causing £100,000 in damage. Richardson's intention was to force the football club to relocate to a new stadium, but the plan failed when Kristiansen left his mobile phone at the scene.

The tall ship Lord Nelson set sail from Glasgow in June on a 100-day voyage around the country as part of celebrations marking the 100th anniversary of the Girl Guides organization, with crews of up to 44 girl guides boarding at different ports along the journey.

Projectile: volcanic materials as high as 5,000 meters (16,400 feet) into the sky
Summary: Mount Sinabung in North Sumatra province erupted on Tuesday, spewing volcanic materials as high as 5,000 meters (16,400 feet) into the sky and depositing ash on nearby villages. The volcano has been active recently with authorities recording 13 ash cloud releases in the past week.

Place: Brickworks Marketplace on South Road at Torrensville
Summary: Brickworks Marketplace, a new shopping mall located on South Road at Torrensville, opened on June 25, 2015. The development includes Woolworths and Big W stores, along with approximately 45 new shops, 700 car parks, and various dining options replacing the former Brickworks Markets.

McDonald re-signed to the Cincinnati Bengals practice squad the following day after being waived on September 5, 2009, and again re-signed to the practice squad the following day after being waived on September 4, 2010.

Speaker: Thai military conscripts
Summary: In March 2020, Amnesty International reported that Thai military conscripts face institutionalized abuse systematically hushed up by military authorities, including violence, sexual assaults, and humiliation, which reflects a culture of power abuse and impunity within the military.

A gang of smugglers, pretending to be ghosts to deter curious locals, are using a ruined castle as their base to smuggle atomic weaponry into a sleepy coastal village. The smugglers' operation is discovered by young reporter and amateur biker Jerry Marsh who investigates sightings of a mysterious hooded figure on a motorbike.

3. Medium: olive oil, paprika, lemon, salt, pepper, harissa, cumin and other spices and herbs
Summary: Moroccan marinated olives are prepared by soaking olives in a mixture of olive oil, paprika, lemon, salt, pepper, harissa, cumin, and various other spices and herbs for up to a week. These marinated olives are an essential part of Moroccan cuisine, served as side dishes to tagines, as components of gourmet brunches, or as appetizers.

Entity: hundreds if not thousands of African migrants
State: locked in heinous conditions reminiscent of Libya's slave camps
Summary: Hundreds if not thousands of African migrants are being kept in heinous conditions in Saudi Arabian detention centers as part of the country's effort to stop the spread of COVID-19. These migrants are subjected to overcrowded rooms, insufficient food and water, physical abuse, and unsanitary facilities with overflowing toilets.

5. Topic: the amendment to the USA Patriot Act
Summary: On July 8th, 2004, GOP leaders persuaded several House members to change their votes on an amendment to the USA Patriot Act that would have barred the Justice Department from searching bookstore and library records. The vote was held open for 23 minutes while they corralled dissident members, resulting in the amendment's defeat with a 210-210 tie.

In January 2018, local authorities in Kasaragod district submitted an 'investigation' report to the State Public Works Department (PWD) for a 128.44-km hill highway project that passes through the district. The report contains detailed information about the 12-meter-wide road with a 7-meter carriageway, serving as a precursor to obtaining technical sanction for the project.

Entity: four women with brooms sliding a 42lb lump of granite across an ice rink
Summary: Prior to the 2006 Winter Olympics, Rhona Martin, one of the four Scottish women who won gold in curling at the 2002 Winter Olympics, was reported to be living on welfare due to financial problems that caused her to live apart from her husband.

Assailant: a member of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad
Place: the Route 405 bus from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem
Summary: On July 6, 1989, a member of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad carried out a suicide attack by boarding the Tel Aviv Jerusalem bus 405 (Route 405) and driving the bus into an abyss, resulting in the murder of 16 people. This attack marked the first Palestinian suicide attack and represented a new development in political violence inside Israel.

1. Communicator: Elizabeth Truss, the early years minister
2. State_of_affairs: plans to reform childcare in England, which would overhaul childcare qualifications and increase the maximum number of children relative to adults in a care establishment
Summary: Elizabeth Truss, the early years minister, outlined plans to reform childcare in England by increasing the maximum number of children per staff member in nurseries and for registered childminders, while also proposing to professionalize the workforce through higher qualifications and better pay to make childcare more widely available.

Supplier: Friends of Stainton and Thornton Green Spaces
Theme: three hectares of community - run open green space
Place: between the villages of Stainton and Thornton in Middlesbrough
Summary: The Friends of Stainton and Thornton Green Spaces group provides three hectares of community-run open green space for local people, located between the villages of Stainton and Thornton in Middlesbrough. The area includes Stainton Quarry and Kell Gate Green, connected by a footbridge across Stainton Beck.

Supported: four surviving original copies of Magna Carta
Summary: The 800th anniversary of Magna Carta occurred on June 15, 2015, with the British Library organizing a special exhibition bringing together the four existing copies of the 1215 manuscript. This significant historical event was supported by the law firm Linklaters in collaboration with Lincoln Cathedral and Salisbury Cathedral.

Rolls Royce, facing allegations of bribery in a scandal involving the Hindustan Aeronautics Limited (HAL), wrote a letter on March 5 offering to return Rs 18 crore to the Indian government, which was the amount paid as commission to its agent Aashmore Private Limited.
Garda Commissioner Nóirín O'Sullivan is extending the powers of the Garda Reserve to include the seizure of vehicles, following an internal review of the 1,000 member voluntary unpaid body.

Speaker: The captain
Content: letting him land at Marseilles, France, to refuel
Summary: The captain of an Air France Boeing 727 successfully convinced Danièle Cravenne, a hijacker who had commandeered the plane, to allow a refueling stop in Marseille, France, where she subsequently released all passengers and most crew before being shot by French police officers disguised as maintenance workers.

Conjoined twins Ronnie and Donnie Galyon had a two-year stay in the hospital after their birth on October 28, 1951, in Beavercreek, Ohio, during which doctors attempted to determine if they could be safely separated, ultimately concluding they could not without risking both twins' lives.

2. Text: Webster 's New International Dictionary , Second Edition ( 1934 )
Summary: William Allan Neilson, who was born in Scotland and taught at various prestigious institutions including Bryn Mawr College, Harvard, and Columbia, served as the editor-in-chief of Webster's New International Dictionary, Second Edition in 1934, alongside authoring critical works on Shakespeare, Burns, and Elizabethan theatre.

The source describes Sir John Smythe as a charming art thief who is the love interest of Vicky Bliss, an American professor of art history. Throughout the Vicky Bliss novel series, Sir John Smythe is involved in various international crimes and adventures alongside Vicky.

The Bolognese, a breed of dog that genuinely enjoys the companionship of people, forms close relationships with their owners and thrives on receiving attention from them. These true companions are known to follow their owners wherever they go, serving as excellent watchdogs while being sweet and affectionate.

In 1998, the rest of Nomans Land island was transferred to the Fish and Wildlife Service for use as a wildlife refuge, primarily for migratory birds, following an effort to clear the island of ordnance in 1997 and 1998.

The music video "Blood on my Hands" by John Ondrasik went viral on YouTube, accumulating more than 250,000 views, before it was temporarily taken down for violating the platform's "graphic content policy" due to images of Taliban atrocities, though YouTube later reinstated it and apologized for the error.

2. Source_symbol: Asterix in Britain and Asterix and the Normans
3. Source_representation: comic books by René Goscinny and Albert Uderzo
4. Target_symbol: Asterix and Obelix : God Save Britannia
Summary: Laurent Tirard directed the fourth film adaptation "Asterix and Obelix: God Save Britannia," translating the comic books "Asterix in Britain and Asterix and the Normans" by René Goscinny and Albert Uderzo into a movie that continues the adventures of Astérix as the mighty Gallic duo travel to England to save the Queen from Cesar's army.

On September 9, 2005, an Air Kasaï Antonov An-26B aircraft crashed north of Brazzaville in the Republic of Congo, killing all 13 people aboard, including four crew members and nine passengers. The plane was flying from Boende in the Democratic Republic of Congo to Kinshasa when it lost contact during a fierce storm before crashing.

Theme: a train carrying some 1,000 French troops from the Italian front
Path: through a stretch of the Alps in southeastern France
Summary: On December 12, 1917, during World War I, a train carrying about 1,000 French troops from Turin, Italy to Lyon, France derailed while descending a steep hill in Modane, France, killing more than 500 soldiers who were traveling through the Alps after being stationed at the Italian front.

Initial_situation: uncommon in operating systems that operate in Protected mode or Long mode
Summary: The BIOS has undergone a change in usage, becoming uncommon in operating systems that operate in Protected mode or Long mode because the system must switch back to real mode for BIOS drivers to run.

Entity: the al-qaeda . net node 's list software
Summary: In mid 2013, the al-qaeda.net node's list software was changed from Majordomo to GNU Mailman following a brief outage, as part of an effort to make the Cypherpunks mailing list more reliable and easier to maintain.

Event: risk their safety, health, and education on commercial farms across the United States
Place: on commercial farms across the United States
Summary: Child farmworkers in the United States risk their safety, health, and education on commercial farms, often working long hours in hazardous conditions without proper protection. They suffer fatalities at more than four times the rate of children working in other jobs and frequently drop out of school due to their demanding work schedules.
In August 1990, a Sons of Silence member shot an Outlaws member during a bar fight in Sturgis, South Dakota, where two other Sons of Silence bikers were also stabbed in the altercation.

On February 13, 2009, at exactly 9 PM, Graham Linehan created a "BadMovieClub" where over 2,000 Twitter users simultaneously pressed 'Play' on the film 'The Happening' and tweeted while watching, creating a collective viewing experience that combined video and Twitter feeds.

A Spice Jet Bombardier Q400 plane with 75 passengers and crew members skidded off the runway at Karnataka's Hubli airport on Sunday evening amid heavy rainfall, resulting in damage to the left landing gear but no injuries were reported.

Entity: several different spots in New York City
Summary: Leslie, after visiting several different spots in New York City one night, went straight to the studio instead of going home because the energy and excitement inspired him to express himself creatively by making music, which led to the creation of his song "Addiction."

Sleep_state: no memory about himself or his past
Summary: On August 19, 1839, Daniel awakens in the Prussian Brennenburg Castle with no memory about himself or his past, only remembering his name, that he lives in Mayfair, and that something is hunting him.

Dr Mark Norman, a marine biologist at James Cook University, has been researching octopuses for over 10 years, during which he has discovered more than 150 new species of octopuses worldwide, including 45 in Australian waters. His work has attracted international attention, resulting in four nature films documenting his discoveries of various octopus species that range from tiny pygmies to massive creatures weighing up to 200 kilograms.

1. Agent: hostilities - only ratings, personnel of the Royal Naval Patrol Service, and officers and ratings of the Royal Navy Volunteer Reserve (RNVR)
3. Salient_entity: landing craft of many different types
5. Place: the No 1 Combined Training Centre, Inveraray, Scotland
Summary: During World War II, hostilities-only ratings, personnel of the Royal Naval Patrol Service, and officers and ratings of the Royal Navy Volunteer Reserve manned minor landing craft operations at the No 1 Combined Training Centre in Inveraray, Scotland. They were responsible for operating various types of landing craft, primarily to safely deliver troops and equipment onto unimproved landing beaches in preparation for the invasion of Europe.
